name: Tanaka-san
description: A friendly elderly man wearing a traditional kimono. He smiles warmly and offers to help visitors.

dialog.greeting: こんにちは！(Konnichiwa!) Welcome to Kyoto. How can I help you today?
dialog.hint: If you're new here, I recommend visiting the teahouse to the north. The owner can teach you about traditional Japanese customs.
dialog.learn: Let me teach you a useful phrase: 'ありがとう' (arigatou) means 'thank you' in Japanese.

name: Yamada-san
description: An elderly woman with gray hair tied in a bun. She moves gracefully as she prepares tea.

dialog.greeting: いらっしゃいませ (Irasshaimase). Welcome to my humble teahouse.
dialog.hint: Tea ceremony is an important part of Japanese culture. We call it 'お茶の作法' (ocha no sahō).
dialog.learn: In formal situations, we say 'よろしくお願いします' (yoroshiku onegaishimasu) when meeting someone, which roughly means 'please treat me well'.

name: Suzuki-sensei
description: A middle-aged teacher with glasses and a friendly smile. She carries several textbooks.

dialog.greeting: こんにちは、生徒さん (Konnichiwa, seito-san). Hello, student!
dialog.hint: Learning requires practice! Try using new words in sentences.
dialog.learn: Here's a useful phrase for students: '分かりません' (wakarimasen) means 'I don't understand'.

name: Sato-san
description: A cheerful young woman organizing activities at the community center. She wears modern clothes with traditional elements.

dialog.greeting: やあ！(Yaa!) Hi there! Welcome to our community center.
dialog.hint: We have language exchange meetings every week. It's a great way to practice!
dialog.learn: Young people often use casual language like 'すごい' (sugoi) which means 'amazing' or 'awesome'.

name: Nakamura-san
description: A local shopkeeper with a friendly demeanor. His small shop sells various traditional and modern items.

dialog.greeting: いらっしゃい (Irasshai)! Welcome to my shop!
dialog.hint: Shopping in Japan often involves learning specific phrases. Try asking 'いくらですか' (Ikura desu ka?) which means 'How much is it?'
dialog.learn: When you want to buy something, you can say 'これをください' (Kore wo kudasai) which means 'Please give me this.'
